sen.j: 伊勢 貞孝（いせ さだたか）は、戦国時代 (日本)の武将。
sen.e: Sadataka ISE was a 'busho' (warlord) who lived in the Sengoku (Japanese Warring States) period.
Sadataka ISE was a 'busho' (Japanese military commander) who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states.
sen.cmt: 「戦国時代」の表記を用語集に合わせて変更
sen.e: Sadataka ISE was a 'busho' (Japanese military commander) who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states.

sen.j: 室町幕府の幕臣である。
sen.e: Sadataka was a 'bakushin' (shogun's retainer) of the Muromachi bakufu (shogunate).
Sadataka was a 'bakushin' (shogun's retainer) of the Muromachi bakufu (shogunate).
Sadataka was a 'bakushin' (shogun's retainer) of the Muromachi bakufu (shogunate).

sen.j: 伊勢貞忠の子として生まれる。
sen.e: Sadataka was born as a son of Sadatada ISE.
Sadataka was born as a son of Sadatada ISE.
Sadataka was born as a son of Sadatada ISE.

sen.j: 天文 (元号)4年（1535年）に父が死去すると、家督を継いで室町幕府政所執事となった。
sen.e: Upon his father's death in 1535, Sadataka succeeded the family estate and became 'mandokoro shitsuji' (chief of Mandokoro which was the Adiministrative Board) of the Muromachi bakufu.
Upon his father's death in 1535, Sadataka took over as head of the the family and became 'mandokoro shitsuji' (chief of Mandokoro which was the Administrative Board) of the Muromachi bakufu.
sen.cmt: 「家督を継いで」の訳を用語集に合わせて変更Administrativeのスペルミスを修正
sen.e: Upon his father's death in 1535, Sadataka took over as head of the the family and became 'mandokoro shitsuji' (chief of Mandokoro which was the Administrative Board) of the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 天文19年（1550年）に第12代将軍・足利義晴臨終の際には枕元に侍り、後継者の足利義輝の補佐を遺言されたといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that in 1550 Sadataka attended the deathbed of the 12th Shogun Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, who willed that Sadataka should assist the next Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.
It is said that in 1550 Sadataka attended the deathbed of the 12th Shogun Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, who willed that Sadataka should assist the next Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.
It is said that in 1550 Sadataka attended the deathbed of the 12th Shogun Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA, who willed that Sadataka should assist the next Shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: しかし三好長慶によって義輝が追放されたのちも京都に留まるなど、義輝との関係は悪化していった。
sen.e: Despite the will, a relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru gradually deteriorated as, for example, Sadataka dared stay in Kyoto after Yoshiteru had banished by Nagayoshi (alternatively, Chokei) MIYOSHI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Despite the will, a relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru gradually deteriorated as, for example, Sadataka dared stay in Kyoto after Yoshiteru had been banished by Nagayoshi (alternatively, Chokei) MIYOSHI.
sen.cmt: had banished by→had been banished by
sen.e: Despite the will, a relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru gradually deteriorated as, for example, Sadataka dared stay in Kyoto after Yoshiteru had been banished by Nagayoshi (alternatively, Chokei) MIYOSHI.

sen.j: （なお、天文20年（1551年）に貞孝と長慶が会談した際、長慶の暗殺未遂事件が勃発している。）
sen.e: (It should be noted that when Sadataka met with Nagayoshi in 1551, an incident of an attempted assassination arose, yet this attempt on Nagayoshi's life failed.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (It should be noted that when Sadataka met with Nagayoshi in 1551, an incident of an attempted assassination on Nagayoshi arose.)
sen.cmt: 後半をすっきりさせました。
sen.e: (It should be noted that when Sadataka met with Nagayoshi in 1551, an incident of an attempted assassination on Nagayoshi arose.)

sen.j: 貞孝は長慶の与党として反長慶の細川晴元等の勢力とたびたび干戈を交えることになる。
sen.e: Taking sides with Nagayoshi, Sadataka often fought against 'anti-Nagayoshi' Harumoto HOSOKAWA and his party.
Taking sides with Nagayoshi, Sadataka often fought against 'anti-Nagayoshi' Harumoto HOSOKAWA and his party.
Taking sides with Nagayoshi, Sadataka often fought against 'anti-Nagayoshi' Harumoto HOSOKAWA and his party.

sen.j: 永禄元年（1558年）に義輝と晴元が攻め寄せると、三好方として戦ったものの、義輝が長慶と和睦して帰京することになると長慶や管領細川氏綱と共にこれを出迎えた。
sen.e: When in 1558 Yoshiteru and Harumoto closed in for attack, Sadataka fought them back on Miyoshi's side, but once Yoshiteru and Nagayoshi were reconcilled and Yoshiteru's return for Kyoto was permitted, Sadataka, together with Nagayoshi and Shogunal Deputy Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA, received Yoshiteru.

When in 1558 Yoshiteru and Harumoto closed in for an attack, Sadataka fought them back on Miyoshi's side, but once Yoshiteru and Nagayoshi were reconciled and Yoshiteru's return for Kyoto was permitted, Sadataka, together with Nagayoshi and Shogunal Deputy Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA, received Yoshiteru.
sen.cmt: for attack→for an attackreconciledのスペルミスを修正
sen.e: When in 1558 Yoshiteru and Harumoto closed in for an attack, Sadataka fought them back on Miyoshi's side, but once Yoshiteru and Nagayoshi were reconciled and Yoshiteru's return for Kyoto was permitted, Sadataka, together with Nagayoshi and Shogunal Deputy Ujitsuna HOSOKAWA, received Yoshiteru.

sen.j: しかし、義輝との関係は修復できず、また、長慶の家臣である松永久秀が台頭するようになると、貞孝は次第に立場を失うようになっていった。
sen.e: The deteriorated relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru was never repaired, which led Sadataka to such difficulties that as Hisahide MATSUNAGA who served Nagayoshi emerged, Sadataka gradually lost his prestige.

The deteriorated relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru was never repaired, which led Sadataka to such difficulties that as Hisahide MATSUNAGA who served Nagayoshi emerged, Sadataka gradually lost his prestige.

The deteriorated relationship between Sadataka and Yoshiteru was never repaired, which led Sadataka to such difficulties that as Hisahide MATSUNAGA who served Nagayoshi emerged, Sadataka gradually lost his prestige.

sen.j: 永禄5年（1562年）には失脚に追い込まれ、このため京都船岡山で挙兵したが、長慶の命を受けた松永久秀の追討を受け、子の貞良と共に戦死した。
sen.e: In 1562 Sadataka's downfall culminated by losing his position, and when Sadataka finally raised an army in Mt. Funaoka ('Funaokayama') in Kyoto, Nagayoshi ordered Hisahide MATSUNAGA to hunt down and kill Sadataka, thus resulting in the death of Sadataka and his son Sadayoshi in battle.

In 1562 Sadataka's downfall culminated by losing his position, and when Sadataka finally raised an army in Mt. Funaoka ('Funaokayama') in Kyoto, Nagayoshi ordered Hisahide MATSUNAGA to hunt down and kill Sadataka, thus resulting in the death of Sadataka and his son Sadayoshi in battle.

In 1562 Sadataka's downfall culminated by losing his position, and when Sadataka finally raised an army in Mt. Funaoka ('Funaokayama') in Kyoto, Nagayoshi ordered Hisahide MATSUNAGA to hunt down and kill Sadataka, thus resulting in the death of Sadataka and his son Sadayoshi in battle.
